title: Minimum Error Rate Training In Statistical Machine Translation
descriptions:
**Abstract:**

This paper investigates the application of Minimum Error Rate (MER) training in the context of Statistical Machine Translation (SMT). It is recognized that many tasks in natural language processing have evaluation criteria that are more complex than simply counting the number of errors made by the system. In particular, for SMT, traditional evaluation metrics such as BLEU and word error rate (WER) are used to measure translation quality. The authors explore methods to optimize SMT model parameters with respect to these automatic evaluation metrics directly.

The paper introduces the use of log-linear models for SMT and discusses the challenges of optimizing these models with respect to evaluation criteria that cannot be directly incorporated into a gradient descent framework due to their non-smooth nature. The authors propose a novel training algorithm that efficiently optimizes an unsmoothed error count, which can also be adapted to handle BLEU and NIST scores. Additionally, the paper presents a baseline translation approach utilizing a set of informative feature functions and dynamic programming techniques for searching the best candidate translations.

The results of the study indicate that optimizing the SMT model parameters using the proposed error rate training criteria leads to improved translation quality on unseen test data compared to traditional maximum mutual information (MMI) training. Furthermore, the paper discusses the importance of selecting the right error criterion for training, as different criteria yield varying results and may not correlate equally well with human assessments of translation quality.

The authors conclude by emphasizing the potential of the proposed training approach to improve machine translation quality by directly optimizing automatic evaluation metrics. They also suggest that this approach can be extended to other tasks in natural language processing that require more sophisticated evaluation criteria beyond simple error counts. Future research directions include investigating the optimal number of parameters that can be estimated using the unsmoothed error rate criterion and evaluating the correlation between different automatic evaluation measures and human judgment of translation quality.

Abstract:

This paper addresses the challenge of optimizing statistical machine translation (SMT) models in alignment with the actual evaluation metrics used for assessing translation quality, such as BLEU and NIST scores. The authors highlight the discrepancy between the assumptions of statistical approaches that focus on minimizing the number of wrong decisions and the complex evaluation criteria that reflect real-world translation quality. They propose alternative training criteria, specifically an unsmoothed error count and a smoothed error count, and introduce a new line optimization algorithm for efficiently optimizing these criteria. Experimental results on a Chinese-English translation task demonstrate that optimizing training with respect to actual error rates leads to better performance on unseen test data. The paper also discusses the potential issues of overfitting with the unsmoothed error count and the choice of the most suitable error criterion for training. The research suggests that improving automatic evaluation measures can lead to direct enhancements in machine translation quality, but also warns that optimizing for these measures may expose and exploit their weaknesses, thus necessitating careful development of evaluation criteria. The authors anticipate that their approach could benefit other natural language processing tasks with complex evaluation metrics beyond simple error counting.

Abstract:

This paper investigates the optimization of model parameters in statistical machine translation (SMT) with a focus on achieving the highest possible translation quality as measured by automatic evaluation criteria, such as word error rate (WER) and BLEU score. The authors examine the use of log-linear models in SMT and propose alternative training criteria that are directly related to translation quality, particularly an unsmoothed error count and a smoothed error count. Additionally, the paper introduces a new line optimization algorithm that efficiently finds the optimal solution along a line for the unsmoothed error count. The training criteria are evaluated in the context of several machine translation (MT) experiments, revealing that certain evaluation criteria, when used as a basis for training, result in significantly better translation quality on unseen test data. The results of the study suggest that optimizing for specific error rates during training can lead to improvements in actual translation quality, which is often correlated with human subjective evaluations of fluency and adequacy. The paper raises questions about the number of parameters that can be estimated using unsmoothed minimum error rate criteria and the potential overfitting issues when optimizing many parameters. It also postulates that future development in automatic evaluation measures could lead to direct improvements in MT quality. The paper concludes that the framework presented could be applied to other natural language processing tasks with complex evaluation criteria, potentially resulting in improved system performance.

Abstract:

This paper addresses the challenge of optimizing statistical machine translation (SMT) systems to improve translation quality as measured by automatic evaluation criteria like word error rate (WER) and BLEU score. Traditional SMT approaches often rely on simplifications such as the zero-one loss function, leading to a mismatch between model training and actual performance evaluation, which considers factors beyond mere decision errors. To address this, the authors introduce Minimum Error Rate (MER) training, which directly optimizes model parameters based on translation quality metrics. They propose novel training criteria and algorithms, including an efficient line optimization algorithm for an unsmoothed error count, which outperforms the Maximum Mutual Information (MMI) criterion traditionally used for SMT.

The paper describes the use of log-linear models for SMT and presents a method for generating candidate translations for training. The approach is empirically evaluated on a Chinese-to-English translation task, demonstrating that training with error rate optimization leads to significant improvements in translation quality on unseen test data. The results suggest that choosing the right error criterion for training yields the best performance when measured using the same criterion on test data. The authors also discuss the potential for overfitting with unsmoothed error counts and the implications for the estimation of model parameters.

The study concludes with reflections on the future of SMT training criteria, emphasizing the importance of developing evaluation metrics that correlate with human assessments of translation quality. The research opens up possibilities for applying the presented framework to other natural language processing tasks with complex evaluation criteria. The work was supported by DARPA-ITO grant 66001-00-1-9814.
